newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa ends narrowly up on arbitrage buying.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa ends narrowly up on arbitrage buying.

text.p: London cocoa futures registered small gains in late arbitrage buying against New York on Wednesday after a flat session.
Traders said the third-quarter German grind which rose by a higher-than-expected seven percent from a year ago to 65,824 tonnes was supportive, but the news failed to spark any buying.
"The German grind was good but the market still can't do anything. It's not a dynamic," said one trader.
Some origin selling, including Nigeria and Cameroon, was still creeping in the market, keeping a lid on prices.
By the close, the benchmark March contract had crawled up to 1,006 stg a tonne, four stg higher on the day, but it was off a session peak of 1,009 stg.
The May 97/May 98 switch was active at 55 stg and 60 stg while Dec/March traded at 28 and 29 stg, traders said.
German traders who cited a cool summer and export activity, said the increase in the grind fitted a generally strong demand picture in Europe. The UK and Dutch grinds were sharply higher.
But the market spotlight is mainly on the Ivory Coast which is expected to announce its farmer price at the end of this week or the beginning of next week.
The Ivorian season officially starts on October 15 and talk is circulating among some traders that purchases could be slightly delayed.
But even so, analysts expect sufficient supplies pouring in once purchases kick off.
"The official starting date will be irrelevant," said one trader.
"People don't want to buy any Decembers. Even if there is a two-week delay, it not going to make December very strong," said another.
Technical resistance is pegged at 1,025 stg for March while support is around 985 stg.
